Home

Right hemispheric stroke

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Rykard,

It was a pleasure caring for you at Lincoln Park Community Hospital.  You were admitted to the hospital because of weakness on your right side, which is concerning for a stroke.  We did an MRI of your brain and found that there was a small area of damage in the right hemisphere of your brain.  This is consistent with a stroke, but we are not sure what caused it.

We treated you with medications to prevent further strokes and 
to control your blood pressure.  Your weakness has improved, 
but you may still have some residual weakness on your right side. 

Please follow up with your neurologist as scheduled below.
 
Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Sawyer in 1-2 weeks to monitor progress and adjust treatment plan as needed for the management of Right hemispheric stroke. Please contact our office to schedule this appointment at least 24 hours in advance. During your follow-up visit, be prepared to discuss any changes in symptoms or concerns you may have experienced since your last appointment with Dr. Julianne Sawyer.

Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Ms. Jensen,

It was a pleasure taking care of you at North Jordan General Hospital.  You were admitted to the 
Pediatric Intensive Care Unit (PICU) with abdominal pain, 
diarrhea and vomiting. Imaging studies showed that your bowel 
was damaged and you had an infection in your abdomen. In order to 
treat this, we made a hole in your abdomen so that gas could escape 
and we started antibiotics. You improved over the next few days 
and were transferred back to the general pediatric floor where 
you continued to improve.

You will be discharged home with the following medications: 

* Dilaudid 2mg every 3 hours for pain
* Lovenox 40 mg twice a day for 8 more doses

Please take all of your medications as prescribed. You should 
start to feel better over the next few days and you can wean off 
of the dilaudid as needed.

Weigh yourself every morning, call MD if weight goes up by >1lb 

You will need to follow-up with Dr. Julianne Marquez in 2 weeks for a re-evaluation of your abdominal pain and diarrhea symptoms. Please schedule this appointment as soon as possible to ensure that you receive the necessary care and attention.

Thank you again for allowing us to be a part of your healthcare 
team! We wish you all the best!

Sincerely,
Your North Jordan General Hospital Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Julianne Marquez in 2 weeks for a re-evaluation of your abdominal pain and diarrhea symptoms, or sooner if you experience any worsening or new symptoms such as severe abdominal pain, vomiting, or bloody stools. Please schedule this appointment as soon as possible to ensure that you receive the necessary care and attention. If you have any questions or concerns before then, please do not hesitate to contact our office. We are here to help!

2. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY 
3. Aspirin 81 mg PO DAILY

Discharge Disposition:
Extended Care
 
Facility:
Home Health Services
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Right renal mass

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
You were admitted to the urology service for a right nephrectomy. 
Your pain is controlled with oral analgesics, and your 
incisional pain will improve over time. You are tolerating a 
regular diet and are able to ambulate independently. Please 
resume all of your home medications except for hydrocodone 
which you should wean off as directed on the medication 
prescription.

Please follow-up with your primary care physician within one 
week of discharge from the hospital, or sooner if you develop 
any new symptoms such as fevers, chills, nausea, vomiting, 
constipation, or any other concerns. 

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner or return to the 
emergency department for any of the following:
*You experience new chest pain, pressure, tightness, or 
 squeezing.
*New or worsening cough, shortness of breath, or wheeze.
*If you are vomiting and cannot keep down fluids or your 
 medications.
*You see blood or dark/black material when you vomit or have a 
 bowel movement.
*You experience burning when you urinate, have blood in your 
 urine, or experience a discharge.
*Your pain is not improving within Torres hours or is not gone 
within 24 hours. Call or return immediately if your pain is 
getting worse, changes location, or moves to your chest or back.

Please take all medications as prescribed by your physicians. 
Do not drink alcohol or drive a car while taking any narcotic 
medication (per the definition of narcotic below). Narcotics 
include oxycodone, hydrocodone, percocet, percazine, dilaudid, 
and morphine.

Please call your doctor or nurse practitioner if you have any 
questions regarding this discharge summary or any new 
instructions.
 
Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Marquez in 2 weeks to monitor the progress of your right renal mass and assess any changes in symptoms or test results. If you experience any worsening of symptoms or concerns between now and then, please contact our office to schedule an urgent appointment with Dr. Julianne Marquez. 

Please note that this follow-up appointment is a crucial part of your care plan, and it's essential that you keep this scheduled appointment unless otherwise instructed by our office. If you need to cancel or reschedule, please provide us with at least 24 hours' notice so we can adjust our schedule accordingly. Thank you for your cooperation in managing your healthcare! 

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your stay here at the hospital. We wish you all the best in your continued recovery and are confident that you will do well post-discharge. If you have any questions or concerns, please don't hesitate to reach out to our office for assistance.

Sincerely,

Your Care Team

6. Clopidogrel 75 mg PO DAILY  
7. Fluticasone Propionate NASAL 1 SPRY NU BID  
8. Furosemide 20 mg PO DAILY  
9. Metoprolol Succinate XL 25 mg PO DAILY  
10. Multivitamins W/minerals 1 TAB PO DAILY  
11. Omeprazole 40 mg PO DAILY  
12. Simvastatin 40 mg PO QPM  

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
PRIMARY DIAGNOSIS
=================
Acute on Chronic Diialysis Dependent Heart Failure

SECONDARY DIAGNOSES
====================
Hypertension
Hyperlipidemia
Chronic Kidney Disease Stage 5
Coronary Artery Disease
Diabetes Mellitus Type II
Asthma
Depression

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Ryder,

It was a pleasure taking care of you during your hospitalization at Northbrook Community Healthcare System..  You were admitted to the hospital with shortness of breath and found to have fluid overload in your body.  Your heart failure worsened and you required dialysis to remove excess fluid from your body.  We gave you intravenous medications to help improve your heart function, which improved your symptoms.  You also had a cardiac catheterization, which showed no significant blockage in the blood vessels supplying blood to your heart.

We are discharging you home on a daily dose of Lasix (a diuretic medication) and we recommend that you continue dialysis three times per week for the next two weeks.  We also recommend that you follow up with your cardiologist and nephrologist as scheduled below.

Please call Dr. Julianne Patel office at Northbrook Community Healthcare System. if you have any questions or concerns.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care!

Sincerely,
Your Northbrook Community Healthcare System. Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Patel in 1-2 weeks to monitor progress and adjust treatment as needed, or sooner if symptoms worsen. Please contact our office to schedule this appointment at least 24 hours in advance. During your follow-up visit, be prepared to discuss any changes in your condition or medication regimen. If you experience severe chest pain, shortness of breath, or difficulty swallowing before your scheduled appointment, seek immediate medical attention by calling the emergency number listed on your discharge papers or visiting the nearest emergency room.

Name:  Jenson Blackwood                  Unit No:   6679464
 
Admission Date:  2025-09-17              Discharge Date:   2025-10-05
 
Date of Birth:  1962-11-24             Sex:   M
 
Service: NEUROLOGY

Discharge Medications:
1. Aspirin EC 325 mg PO DAILY 
RX *aspirin 325 mg 1 tablet(s) by mouth daily Disp #*30 Tablet 
Refills:*0
2. Metoprolol Succinate XL 50 mg PO DAILY 
3. Atorvastatin 80 mg PO QPM 
4. Levothyroxine Sodium 100 mcg PO DAILY 

 
Discharge Disposition:
Home
 
Discharge Diagnosis:
Primary diagnosis: 
- Right frontotemporal ICH
Secondary diagnoses: 
- Hypertension

 
Discharge Condition:
Mental Status: Clear and coherent.
Level of Consciousness: Alert and interactive.
Activity Status: Ambulatory - Independent.

 
Discharge Instructions:
Dear Mr. Blackwood,

You were admitted to the hospital after you developed a 
bleeding in your brain called an intracerebral hemorrhage (ICH). 
The bleeding was located on the right side of your brain, near 
the front and top part of your head. You underwent imaging with 
a CT scan, which showed that there is no more active bleeding in 
your brain. You were also seen by a neurosurgeon who determined 
that you do not need surgery to remove the blood from your brain.

During this admission, we made some changes to your medications 
to help prevent future bleeds. We stopped taking you off of 
Aspirin and started you on Metoprolol (another blood pressure 
medication). You should continue to take Aspirin 325mg daily for 
the next month and then stop taking it.

You were also found to have an abnormal heart rhythm called a 
SVT. This is likely related to the stress of your recent bleed, 
but we are not sure what caused it. We treated you with IV 
medications that helped control the SVTs. You should follow up 
with your cardiologist who will help determine why this was 
happening.

You were also found to have a low blood pressure on admission. 
We gave you IV fluids and medications that helped improve your 
blood pressures.

It is very important that you continue to take all of your 
medications as prescribed. You should follow up with your PCP 
and neurologist in the next few weeks to make sure that you are 
doing well and do not have any worsening symptoms from this 
bleed.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care,
Your Neurology Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Please schedule a follow-up appointment with Dr. Julianne Marquez in 2-3 days to review test results and discuss further management of your condition. During this visit, please be prepared to discuss any changes in symptoms or concerns you may have since your last appointment. If you experience any severe or worsening symptoms before then, contact our office immediately for assistance. We look forward to seeing you soon! 

 
Sincerely,
Your Neurology Team
 
 
*Please note that this is a sample discharge summary and 
should be customized according to the patient's specific needs 
and medical history.*

ready to be discharged home.

plenty of water daily and consider a stool softener (such as Colace)

movements, please call your physician or nurse practitioner for 
further advice.

Advil, etc. unless told by your cardiologist that it is okay to 
take these medications.

cardiologist as listed below.

fainting, severe headaches or any other symptoms that are of 
concern to you, please seek medical attention immediately. 

Sincerely,
Your Southview Medical Center Team

which showed evidence of a urinary tract infection (UTI).  We 
started you on antibiotics to treat this UTI.  Your symptoms have 
resolved as expected.

Please continue to take all of your medications as prescribed.  
We made no changes to your home regimen.

If you experience any worsening shortness of breath, chest pain, 
palpitations, dizziness or lightheadedness, please seek medical 
attention immediately.

Thank you for allowing us to participate in your care,
Your Southshore Community Hospital Team
 
Followup Instructions:
Return to see Dr. Julianne Marquez in 1 week for a re-evaluation of your primary diagnosis and to discuss any changes in treatment plan as necessary. If symptoms worsen before then, please contact our office immediately to schedule an urgent appointment with Dr. Julianne Marquez. We will also be sending you a follow-up lab work request at this time; please have these results ready for discussion during your next visit. Thank you! 
- Your Southshore Community Hospital Care Team
